instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no water damage,
came with short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL>, i was replaced UB300 and UB400, now the Mac is on but not charging.
20v 0.6a with good know battery.
working fine just with charger or just with battery.
PPBUS with battery 10.6v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
Is the battery percentage reported correctly?
Check voltage and diode mode at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
yes the correct percentage.
charger and battery connected:
SMBUS__2/<SIGNAL>3_SDA_Q</SIGNAL> 0V  2 is O.L / 3 is 500
SMBUS__2/<SIGNAL>3_SCL_Q</SIGNAL> 0V  2 is O.L / 3 is 500
SMBUS__SMC_5_G3_SCL 3.4V
SMBUS__SMC_5_G3_SDA 3.4V
SMBUS__SMC_4_G3H_SDA/SCL 3.4 600
SMBUS__SMC_2_S4_SDA/SCL 0V O.L

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
"charger and battery connected"
Did you check in diode mode with power applied on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: NO of course not.. just the voltage measuring

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
"SMBUS__SMC_5_G3_SCL 3.4V
SMBUS__SMC_5_G3_SDA 3.4V"
Did you see any other lines connected to battery bus?
Don't waste time with irrelevant measurments.
Post diode mode to ground...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: do you mean all the BUS/MBUS lines?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
NO man.
Do you have more than two lines on battery bus???

Post diode mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
wait there is new news..
the mac TURN ON just with charger and charger with battery "alone" (without the battery data cable).
but with the battery data cable is NOT turn on. 
the battery is fine with 100% charge was checking with other board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
SMBUS__SMC_5_G3_SCL 400
SMBUS__SMC_5_G3_SDA 400

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
Check <TRANSISTOR>Q7065</TRANSISTOR> for short D-S.
Also check ohm resistance over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: all good (compare with good board)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: Do you get 2 ohm over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: 2.5ohm good and bad boards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: Check J6951 and its flex for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: Check for knocked off components, or broken traces.

threads.message:

can be ISL or something from the UB300/400 area?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_USBC_INT_L</SIGNAL> -  3.4v   300

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
Try first changing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.
If still the same, change SMC.

the mac recognized the battery but it gave the cable sign instead the  lightning sign.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message: <SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q4</SIGNAL> didnt get 13v so i was replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7040</TRANSISTOR> now there is 13V on <SIGNAL>TBA_GATE_Q4</SIGNAL> but still the same 20v 0.8a charger with battery(before its turn on) is its on is 5v 1.4a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not charging.
threads.message:
Did you remove and check <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> too?
You can easy check an MOSFET (out of board), if open/close its channel.
Be aware of R/<CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR>/40 also.
